poem:
Begin the poem below:

The number 42 flickers on the windshield like a promise at dawn.  
Engine breathes a low rumble—diesel and rain mingled on my tongue.  
I curl into the seat’s vinyl curves, feeling the bus shudder awake.

We surge forward through empty avenues,  
swerving around a prowling gang of shadows—  
a gaggle of geese frozen in my path.  
No braking for honks or flapping wings;  
we slip past them, undeterred,  
our journey too restless to pause.  

Ahead, a brick wall erupts in spray-painted riot—  
letters bleeding cobalt, crimson, and sunburst yellow.  
We halt mid-block, metal doors sighing open,  
to drink in that electric pulse of color.  
Passengers lean out, noses catching the sharp tang  
of fresh paint and city gasoline.

The wheels whisper secrets along cracked asphalt,  
a Morse code that dances with neon reflections.  
Steam coils from manhole covers, rising like ghosts,  
each breath a mirror of the streets we trace.  
Footfalls, conversations, the hiss of closing doors—  
we collect these scattered sounds like talismans.

Through plate-glass windows the skyline shifts,  
towering glass and concrete breathing in unison.  
I taste the edge of dusk on my lips,  
the lull between stoplights and open road.  
Route 42 prowls the arteries of this city,  
neither saint nor villain, but alive in every turn.
